Detailed Syllabus: Introduction; Evolution of Cognitive Science; A free-form discussion on consciousness; Empirical approaches in cognitive science; Brain: Organization; Intro to sensation and perception; Sensory systems; Perception and Perceptual Learning, Cross-modal interactions; Vision; Attention; Learning; Development; Memory; Language and Cognition; Knowledge Representation; Special topics: e.g. Music, mind, and technology; Several debate sessions with student debate teams

Course Description: This course provides a comprehensive introduction to the scientific study of psychology, exploring its historical foundations and diverse methodologies. It delves into core domains such as neuroscience, emotion, personality, social cognition, learning, and life-span development. The curriculum also addresses psychological health and intervention strategies. Students will analyze psychological phenomena through various perspectives, understand research ethics, and apply evidence-based knowledge to develop critical thinking and foster personal and professional effectiveness.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Introduction - Psychology as a Science, Goals of Psychology, History of Psychology.
Unit 2: Methods - Research methods for psychological observations.
Unit 3: Health & Psychology - Psychological health and disorders, Neuroscience and behaviour, Emotion.
Unit 4: Social & Personality - Social, Psychological interventions and treatments, Personality.
Unit 5: Cognitive - Attention, Gender, Memory.
Unit 6: Learning & Development - Learning, Perception, Life-span development, Intelligence

Course Description: This course provides a comprehensive introduction to fundamental biological principles, starting with the cellular and chemical foundations of life, including biomolecular structures and functions. It progresses to explore bioenergetics, metabolism, and the physical principles governing cellular processes. The curriculum then delves into genetic foundations, covering DNA, gene expression, replication, and evolutionary mechanisms. Students will also investigate cell signaling, DNA manipulation techniques, and the computational challenges in modern biology, preparing them to analyze complex biological information and apply interdisciplinary approaches.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Cellular foundations: Cell organelles, Membranes and cellular compartments, Tree of life.
Unit 2: Chemical foundations: Biomolecules, Structure and function.
Unit 3: Physical foundations: Bioenergetics, Catalysis, Enzymes, Photosynthesis, Respiration.
Unit 4: How cells obtain energy from the food - metabolism.
Unit 5: Genetic foundations: DNA, Genes, chromosomes, Genomes, Mutations.
Unit 6: Evolutionary foundations, Systematics.
Unit 7: DNA Replication, Repair, and Recombination - an overview.
Unit 8: How Cells Read the Genome: From DNA to Protein.
Unit 9: Control of Gene expression.
Unit 10: Cell Signaling, Cell cycle.
Unit 11: Analyzing and manipulating DNA.
Unit 12: Introduction to sequencing and computational challenges

Course Description: This course provides a foundational understanding of economics, exploring its diverse definitions and the historical evolution of major schools of thought, including Neoclassical, Marxist, and Keynesian. Students will delve into core microeconomic principles of decision-making and market structures, alongside macroeconomic theories encompassing aggregate demand, supply, inflation, and fiscal policy. The curriculum also introduces international trade dynamics and exchange rate determination. Emphasizing distinct economic conditions in developing nations, the course explores economics' interdisciplinary connections, preparing students to analyze complex social phenomena and inform relevant policy interventions.
Detailed Syllabus: 1. ‘Ways of doing economics: Different views on scope and definition of economics. Alternative schools of economic thought- Neoclassical, Marxist, Keynesian.
2. Theoretical foundations of microeconomics: Agent based understanding of decision making individuals and firms. Market structure and game theory. Welfare economics, Information economics.

3. Theoretical foundations of macroeconomics: Macroeconomic measurement. Aggregate demand, aggregate supply and determination of output. Inflation and Unemployment, Monetary and Fiscal Policy. Banking and the role of finance in the economy.
4. Introduction to the open economy: Basic trade theory- absolute advantage, comparative advantage, Heckscher-Ohlin Model. Exchange rate determination. External accounts of an economy.
5. Interdisciplinary engagements with economics: Economics and psychology. Economics and computational science, economics and climate science

Course Description: This course provides a foundational exploration of film studies, introducing core analytical concepts like mise-en-scène, cinematography, editing, sound, and narrative. It delves into fundamental theoretical conversations on medium specificity, realism, and film phenomenology, including historical perspectives such as the Soviet School and digital cinema. The curriculum also examines influential global cinema movements, including German Expressionism, New Wave, and Noir. Students will develop a comprehensive understanding of cinema as a complex artistic medium, industrial practice, and cultural phenomenon, fostering critical interpretation of its role in art and politics.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Basic terms of analysis and interpretation. Misѐ-en-Scѐne, Cinematography, Editing, Sound, Narrative, Genre.
Unit 2: Fundamental conversations on medium specificity, Realism in Cinema, Phenomenology of film, the Soviet School, Digital Cinema.
Unit 3: Introduction to cinema movements. May include – German Expressionism, New Wave/s, Noir, Indian art film movement

Course Description: This course provides a comprehensive introduction to the discipline of History, exploring its foundational concepts and methodologies. Students will investigate how historians understand time and space, critically examining the nature of historical facts and the ongoing debate surrounding objectivity. The curriculum covers major theoretical models of historical interpretation and various analytical methods, including source criticism, inductive/deductive reasoning, and qualitative/quantitative approaches. Additionally, it offers insights into memory studies, heritage, and public history. Through this engagement, students will develop the capacity to analyze historical narratives, evaluate methodologies, assess primary evidence, and formulate a nuanced understanding of the past.
Detailed Syllabus: (1) Historical Time and Space: In this module students will be introduced to how historians have understood the flow of time and periodised time into historical ages.
(2) Historical Fact and Objectivity: This module will define the historical fact, the different interpretations of what a fact is, and the debate among historians relating to historical objectivity.
(3) The Main Theories of History: In this module students will be exposed to the main theoretical models of historical interpretation.

(4) The Main Methods of Historical Analysis: This module will focus on source criticism, the advantages and limitation of the inductive and deductive methods, oral history, qualitative and quantitative methods.
(5) Memory, heritage and public history: This module will provide students brief introductions to the fields of memory studies, heritage studies and public history

Course Description: This course introduces the scientific study of human language, exploring its fundamental and unique characteristics. Students investigate core linguistic levels, including phonetics, phonology, morphology, and syntax, from both synchronic and diachronic perspectives. The curriculum further examines broader areas like sociolinguistics, language acquisition, historical linguistics, writing systems, and the Paninian grammatical tradition. Through theoretical frameworks and practical data analysis, students develop a robust understanding of linguistic analysis, preparing them to explore diverse languages and contribute to text processing applications.
Detailed Syllabus: 1. What is language? Difference between human language and Animal languages. Natural language, Formal language and Artificial language, Characteristic features of human language, what we know about language.
2. Study of Human language – the field of Linguistics.
3. Looking at language from synchronic and diachronic points of view.

4. Areas of Study from structural perspective: a) Syntagmatic and paradigmatic aspects of language structure; b) Levels of structural analysis: Phonetics, Phonology, Morphology, Syntax; c) From evolution perspective: Historical Linguistics; d) From usage perspective: Sociolinguistics; e) From Psychological perspective: Mechanisms of language acquisition; f) Indian Grammatical Tradition: Paninian grammatical model; g) Writing Systems

Course Title: Introduction to Neural and Cognitive Modeling
Course Description: This course introduces the foundational principles and applications of neural and cognitive modeling, exploring how mathematical and computational methods illuminate brain function. Topics range from single-neuron biophysical models (e.g., Hodgkin-Huxley, LIF) and network-level dynamics like population coding and neuroplasticity, to abstract models of higher cognitive functions such as perception, memory, and language, alongside various learning rules. Students will analyze, evaluate, and design computational solutions for neuroscience problems, developing a critical understanding of these models' strengths and limitations in explaining brain, mind, and behavior, fostering functional and practical insights.
Detailed Syllabus: Part I: Single-Neuron Level Models: Introduction to Neuroscience; Passive membrane models, Leaky Integrate and Fire (LIF) models, Hodgkin-Huxley model, Cable models of dendrites, Synapse model, Compartmental models.

Part II: Network Level Models: Neural population codes; information representation; neural encoding and decoding; hierarchy and organization of sensory systems; Spiking Network models of sensory systems; Neuroplasticity and learning.

Part III: Abstract Models: Introduction to Hebbian, Competitive and Error-driven learning rules; Reinforcement learning, Neural Network models of Perception, Attention, Memory, Language and Executive Function

Course Description: This course introduces students to the nature and scope of philosophical inquiry as a rational, second-order discipline. It critically examines core epistemological questions concerning knowledge validity and its sources through thinkers like Descartes, Hume, and Kant. Subsequently, the curriculum explores distinct approaches to human existence and consciousness via Existentialism (Nietzsche, Sartre) and Phenomenology (Husserl, Heidegger). The course then delves into Hermeneutics, investigating interpretation and narrative identity. Students will develop sophisticated analytical skills to distinguish objective and subjective knowledge, analyze self-understanding, and critically evaluate diverse perspectives on belief formation.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Nature and the Scope of Philosophy: Philosophy as a Rational Inquiry, Second-order discipline, Phronesis and the Good Life (Aristotle).
Unit 2: Epistemology: Impression and Ideas (David Hume), Cogito Ergo Sum (Descartes), Transcendental Aesthetic and Categories (Kant).
Unit 3: Existentialism: Übermensch and Eternal Recurrence of the Same (Nietzsche), Bad Faith and Authenticity (Sartre).
Unit 4: Phenomenology: Intentionality and Horizon (Edmund Husserl); Ready-to-hand and Disclosure (Martin Heidegger).
Unit 5: Hermeneutics: Hermeneutical Circle (Gadamer); Narrative Identity (Paul Ricouer)

Course Description: This course introduces students to the fundamental concepts and foundational theories of Political Science. It defines politics, the state, and governmental forms, then delves into core political concepts such as liberty, equality, justice, rights, and democracy. A significant portion examines the structure, functions, and philosophical underpinnings of the Indian Constitution, its democratic institutions (Parliament, Executive, Judiciary), federalism, secularism, and the electoral process. Students will develop a critical understanding of political systems, particularly in India, enabling them to analyze contemporary challenges and formulate policy perspectives for reforms within the Indian political system.
Detailed Syllabus: Module 1: Introduction to various perspectives on how we define politics and its domain; Nature and scope of Political Science as a field of knowledge; Meaning and origin of State: divine theory and social contract theory; Forms and functions of government.

Module 2: Brief introduction to key concepts of Political Science; Liberty: Negative and Positive; Equality: Equality of Opportunity; Justice: Social Justice; Rights: Legal Rights and Human Rights; Democracy: Idea and Practice.

Module 3: Philosophy and features of Indian constitution, Structure and functions of Parliament (Legislature), Prime Minister and his cabinet (Executive), Supreme Court of India (Judiciary); Balance of Power.
Module 4: Structure and functioning of federalism in India; centre-state relations; Meaning and interpretation of secularism in the Indian context; Provisions for unity in diversity.
Module 5: History and Features of Party system in India; National Parties and State Parties; Trends in the Party System; Electoral Process, Election Commission, Contemporary Challenges and Reforms

Course Description: This course provides a rigorous introduction to Quantum Field Theory, exploring the motivations behind describing nature through quantum fields rather than wave functions. It covers elements of classical field theory, symmetries, and Noether's theorem, then transitions to functional quantization, path integrals, and Feynman diagrams for scalar and Dirac fields. Students will learn the S-matrix formalism, how to calculate scattering cross-sections, and delve into Quantum Electrodynamics (QED). The course aims to equip students with the ability to apply second quantization techniques and calculate transition amplitudes for fundamental physical processes.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Introduction: review of backgrounds, motivations for QFT.
Unit 2: Elements of Classical Field Theory: symmetries and No ether's theorem.
Unit 3: Functional Formalism: path integral formalism, functional quantization, Feynman diagrams, quantization of scalar field, phi-4 theory.
Unit 4: S-matrix: scattering cross-section and decay rates, from Feynman diagrams to S-matrix.
Unit 5: Dirac Field: Dirac equation and its solutions, gamma matrices, quantization, Green's function.
Unit 6 Quantum Electrodynamics (QED): Feynman rules for QED, cross-section of simple QED processes.
Unit 7 Introduction to Renormalization

Course Description: This course provides a foundational understanding of remote sensing, focusing on the acquisition and analysis of Earth observation data. Students will explore the physics of electromagnetic radiation and its interaction with Earth materials, critical for understanding optical remote sensing processes. The curriculum covers data acquisition, sensor characteristics, pre-processing, and image enhancement. Emphasis is placed on both conventional and advanced computational methods for information extraction, including multispectral and object-based classifications. The course concludes by discussing diverse applications in environmental monitoring, urban planning, and agriculture, alongside an introduction to emerging technologies like drones and radar, preparing students to extract and interpret spatial information effectively.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit-1: Introduction to Remote sensing: What is remote sensing? Earth Observation Satellites and Platforms.
Unit-2: Physics of Electro Magnetic Radiation (EMR) Radiation laws applicable to remote sensing: EMR interaction with Atmosphere and Earth materials.
Unit-3: Data acquisition and image characteristics, Image pre-processing, Image Enhancement.
Unit-4: Information extraction- Multispectral classification – Visual Interpretation- Digital classification. Object based image classification, Stereo Imagery.
Unit-5: Major applications in Vegetation /wildlife; Hydrology/Agriculture, Disaster management.
Unit-6: Overview of Advanced topics: Drone, Hyperspectral and thermal, Microwave/Radar

Course Description: This workshop introduces the fundamental principles and practical applications of Internet of Things (IoT) systems, with a focus on structural engineering contexts. It covers essential electrical circuit analysis, embedded system components like microcontrollers, sensors, and actuators. Participants will learn C programming for Arduino and ESP32 platforms, exploring hardware interfacing, communication protocols, and advanced peripherals. The curriculum extends to IoT networking, cloud computing, data analysis, interoperability standards, and security considerations. Upon completion, learners will be equipped to design, develop, and implement robust IoT-based solutions for complex real-world problems, from conceptualization to visualization.
Detailed Syllabus: 1. Basic properties of electricity and electrical circuits - DC, Voltage, Current, Power, Energy, Resistance, Ohm’s Law, Circuit Diagrams.
2. Kirchoff’s voltage and current laws, series and parallel resistance, Voltage and Current divider.
3. Online Simulations using TinkerCAD.
4. Basic Circuits, Mesh analysis, Node analysis.
5. What is IoT, Embedded Systems, Components of Embedded Systems, Microcontrollers, Sensors and Actuators, Analog/Digital conversion, Internet structure, Protocols, TCP/IP.
6. Arduino Environment, C Programming, Arduino programming and debugging, URAT Protocol.
7. Interfacing with Arduino, Pulse Width Modulation, Arduino Libraries, I2C communication, Arduino Shields.
8. Peripherals: RTC, ADC channels, resolution, onboard memory, power, external/internal watchdog.
9. Communications and Networking in IoT.
10. Cloud Computing and Data Analysis.
11. Interoperability Standards and security.
12. Dashboard and Visualization.
13. Documentation and Productization

Course Description: This course explores the intricate relationship between language and society, focusing on core principles of sociolinguistics. Students will investigate phenomena such as language variation, dialects, and contact situations like bilingualism and code-switching. The curriculum delves into social stratification of language, cultural influences, and critical perspectives on language and power dynamics. Practical applications include analyzing language data using learned concepts, interpreting findings for computational models, and developing real-world solutions. Through team-based projects, students will gain confidence in designing and implementing computational models in authentic social contexts.
Detailed Syllabus: 1. Language Variation: Sociolinguistics and sociology of language, Variation in language, Linguistic variables and social variables. Speech Communities, Language, Dialects and Varieties. Standard language and Standardization, Regional and social dialects. Register, styles. Dialectology.

2. Language Contact: Bilingualism/Multilingualism, borrowing, code mixing/switching, pidginization and creolization, convergence, language maintenance/shift, language acquisition in a multilingual setting. Diglossia with or without bilingualism.

3. Social stratification of language. Inherent variability. Sociolinguistic variables: indicator, marker, stereotype. Style shifting. Hypercorrection. Language variation and language change. Social motivation for sound change. Sociolinguistic devices for effective communication. Communicative competence. Politeness strategies. Pronouns of power and solidarity.
4. Language and Culture: Directions of influence. The Whorfian hypothesis.
5. Critical Sociolinguistics. Language and power. Language and social attitudes: gender, race, education.
6. Language planning: codification and elaboration

Course Description: This course delves into the intricate psychological and neuroscientific underpinnings of learning and memory. It explores foundational concepts like classical and operant conditioning, habituation, and various memory systems including episodic, semantic, skill, and working memory, examining their neural network representations. The curriculum further investigates the influence of emotion, social interactions, and lifespan development on these cognitive processes. Students will develop the ability to critically analyze experimental research, apply behavioral principles to brain models, and design innovative experiments, thereby advancing their understanding and contributing to the field.
Detailed Syllabus: Introductory Module: Psychology of Learning and Memory; Neuroscience of Learning and Memory.

Learning Module: Habituation, Sensitization, and Familiarization: Learning About Repeated Events; Classical Conditioning: Learning to Predict Significant Events; Operant Conditioning: Learning the Outcome of Behaviours; Generalization, Discrimination Learning, and Concept Formation.
Memory Module: Episodic Memory and Semantic Memory; Skill Memory; Complementary learning systems in the brain /Memory network in the brain; Working Memory and Cognitive Control.

Integrative Module: Emotional/Stress Influences on Learning and Memory; Social Learning and Memory: Observing, Interacting, and Reenacting; Development and Aging: Learning and Memory Across the Lifespan

Course Description: This course explores the multifaceted historical processes that have shaped contemporary India. Beginning with an overview of colonial rule and the independence movement, it examines the nation's founding moments, including Partition and the Constitution's creation. The curriculum then traces India's political, social, and economic evolution from the 1950s to the 2000s, analyzing significant transitions and long-term societal trends like urbanization and education. Students will develop a critical understanding of key historical narratives, scholarly frameworks, and conceptual foundations, preparing them to engage deeply with related topics and cultivate their own research perspective.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Colonial Background: overview of the main features of colonial rule and of India’s independence movement; important social and economic trends beginning in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.
Unit 2: Independence, Partition, Constitution of the New Nation-State: detailed study of Independence and the making of the Constitution of India.

Unit 3: 1950s to 2000s: overview of how India’s polity and society passed through transition and faced new challenges; major landmarks of independent India’s political, social, economic, and development journey.
Unit 4: Long-term Processes: literacy and education, infant mortality and sex-ratios, migration and urbanization, and travel and communication

Course Description: This course delves into the fundamental concepts of probability and statistics, establishing a robust theoretical foundation. Students will explore axiomatic probability, conditional probability, and Bayes' Rule, progressing to an in-depth study of random variables, common discrete and continuous distributions, expectation, and variance. Key topics include linearity of expectation, tail bounds (Markov, Chebyshev), the Law of Large Numbers, and the Central Limit Theorem. The curriculum culminates in practical applications such as Maximum Likelihood and Bayesian estimation techniques, enabling students to create, analyze, and apply mathematical models for real-world problem-solving and data analysis.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Sample Spaces, Counting, Uniform Probability, Axioms of Probability, Continuous Probability Spaces, Conditional Probability, Bayes Rule, Independence.

Unit 2: Random Variables, PMFs, Discrete Probability Distributions, Multiple Random Variables, Expectation, Variance, Covariance, Standard distributions of Bernoulli, Binomial, Geometric, Gaussian, Exponential, Poisson.
Unit 3: Continuous Probability Distributions, Tail Bounds (Markov, Chebyshev, Chernoff), Law of Large Numbers, Central Limit Theorem.
Unit 4: Bayesian Statistics, Maximum Aposteriori Estimation, Maximum Likelihood Estimation, Confidence Intervals

Course Description: This course provides a rigorous foundation in Linear Algebra, a cornerstone for various scientific and engineering disciplines. It systematically covers fundamental concepts including vector spaces, linear transformations, and methods for solving systems of linear equations. Students will explore eigenvalues, eigenvectors, inner product spaces, and projections. The curriculum culminates in advanced topics such as Spectral and Singular Value Decompositions. Emphasis is placed on developing analytical proof skills and applying these principles to design dimension reduction techniques and create mathematical models for real-world problems like image compression and Principal Component Analysis.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Vector spaces, subspaces, Linear dependence, Span, Basis, Dimension, Finite dimension vector spaces Linear transformation, Range and Null space of linear transformation, Rank Nullity Theorem, Sylvester's Law, Matrix representation of a linear transformation for finite dimensional linear spaces, Matrix operations, change of basis, Rank of a Matrix, Range and Null Space of a matrix representing a linear transformation. Linear spaces with inner product.

Unit 2: System of Linear Equations, Row-echelon form, reduced row-echelon form. Gauss-Jordon elimination, Solution of linear systems using Gauss-Jordon elimination, matrix inversion by Gauss Jordon elimination, Understanding Range Space and Solution Space using Rank-Nullity Theorem.
Unit 3: Eigenvalues and Inner product: Eigenvalues & Eigenvectors, Norms, Inner Products and Projections, Applications like Analysis of Random Walks.
Unit 4: Advanced Topics: Spectral & Singular Value Decomposition Theorems, Applications of SVD and Best Fit Subspaces

Course Description: This course delves into mobile robotics, focusing on the fundamental principles of robotic perception and navigation. It begins with exploring coordinate frame transformations and advanced pose representations essential for robot kinematics. Subsequently, the curriculum covers LIDAR-based mapping and localization, alongside principles of computer vision, including camera modeling and calibration. Emphasis is placed on backend optimization techniques, such as Bundle Adjustment, crucial for Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM). Students will analyze, apply, and simulate advanced algorithms to address real-world challenges in robotic perception and autonomous navigation.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Representation of Coordinate Frames, Rotation Matrices, Homogenous Transforms, Quaternions and Axis Angle Representations.
Unit 2: LIDAR based Mapping and Localization.
Unit 3: Principles of Computer Vision: Camera Modelling, Calibration, Reconstruction and Resection.
Unit 4: Backend Optimization for LIDAR Based SLAM, Bundle Adjustment

Course Description: Modern Coding Theory explores the theoretical foundations and practical applications of error-correcting codes for reliable data transmission. The course delves into core concepts such as channel capacity and introduces various capacity-achieving codes, including LDPC and Reed Muller. Students will analyze their respective decoding algorithms, such as Message Passing Decoding and majority logic. Furthermore, the curriculum covers advanced topics like recursive constructions for Berman and Polar Codes, emphasizing their capacity achievability. This course provides a comprehensive understanding of contemporary coding techniques crucial for designing robust communication systems, particularly relevant for 5G and future wireless technologies.
Detailed Syllabus: 1. Channels and their Capacity; Notion of Capacity achieving Codes; Examples codes achieving capacity on various channels. Application in 5G and beyond.
2. Basics of Block Codes, Concept of LDPC Codes, Idea of Code Ensembles.
3. Message Passing Decoding of LDPC Codes, Analysis of decoding via Density evolution.
4. Reed Muller Codes: Definition, Properties, and Proof of Capacity achieving nature in Binary Erasure Channels, Idea of Capacity Achieving nature in other binary memoryless channels..
5. Recursive Constructions for Berman Codes and Polar Codes: Definitions, basic properties, idea of capacity achieving nature in BMS channels

Course Description: This course delves into Modern Complexity Theory, exploring fundamental models of computation, including Turing Machines and Boolean Circuits, alongside inherent impossibility results. Students will thoroughly examine key complexity measures (time, space, depth) and established classes (P, NP, PSPACE, NC), understanding their relationships and hierarchies. A central focus will be on designing reductions to demonstrate problem hardness and completeness for various classes. The curriculum also covers advanced topics like probabilistic and randomized complexity. Upon completion, learners will be adept at synthesizing rigorous proofs for resource bounds and applying principles of NP-Completeness to manage computational intractability in problem design.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Models of Computation and Impossibility Results: Turing Machines, Circuits, Encoding of Problems, Halting Problem, Shannon’s Counting Lower bound.
Unit 2: Complexity Measures and Classes: Time, Space, Depth measures of complexity, Time, Space hierarchy theorems, Nondeterminism, Savitch’s theorem, P, NP, P/poly, PSPACE, EXP, L, NL.
Unit 3: Completeness and Hardness Reductions: 3SAT, Cook-Levin Theorem, NP-Complete, NL Complete, Hardness reductions for common problems like Vertex Cover, Independent Set, Knapsack etc.
Unit 4: Advanced Topics: Definitions and relationships between PH, RP, BPP, NC including theorems like Karp-Lipton, Adleman’s theorem, Der and omization Techniques

Course Description: This Music Workshop offers a comprehensive exploration of musical concepts and practices. Students will delve into diverse writings by musicians and musicologists, gaining an introduction to fundamental musical principles with a focus on Indian music. The course incorporates guided music listening sessions across various genres to appreciate 'Sadhana', alongside practical exercises covering notes, rhythm, scales, ragas, and language. This foundational work culminates in the development of individual musical projects, fostering an understanding of music's research potential, its integral role in human life, and an interdisciplinary perspective, empowering students to create original work.
Detailed Syllabus: 1. Text reading: The students will be introduced to a wide range of topics through the writings of different musicians, musicologists and music rasikas.
2. Introduction to all the basic concepts of music with special focus on Indian music.
3. Music listening: Music of different genres will be played for the students to observe and understand the importance of ‘Sadhana’ in music.
4. Practical exercises: Various exercises based on notes, rhythm, scales, ragas and language.
5. Discussions on topics that students want to take up as their course project (individual sessions relevant to their topic)

Course Description: This course establishes a foundational understanding of electrical networks, signals, and systems. It comprehensively covers fundamental circuit elements, network theorems, and both transient and steady-state analysis, including sinusoidal inputs and two-port networks. The curriculum then progresses to signal representation, Fourier series, and system characterization using differential equations, block diagrams, convolution, and impulse responses. Finally, transfer function analysis with Laplace transforms is explored. Upon completion, students will be proficient in analyzing complex circuit behaviors and applying analytical techniques to solve practical problems involving signals and dynamic systems.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Circuit elements
Unit 2: Network theorems
Unit 3: Transient and Steady state analysis
Unit 4: Sinusoidal input and phasors
Unit 5: Two port networks
Unit 6: Signals, representation, sinusoids, and Fourier series
Unit 7: Systems and representations – differential equations, block diagram, operator, and functional form
Unit 8: Convolution integral and impulse response
Unit 9: Transfer function – Laplace transform, poles and zeros

Course Title: Open Quantum systems and Quantum Thermodynamics
Course Description: This course explores the fundamental kinematics and dynamics of open quantum systems. Beginning with a review of quantum mechanics, it progresses through pure and mixed states, measurement theory, and the intricacies of non-unitary evolution, including completely positive trace preserving maps and entanglement characterization. The syllabus details general quantum dynamical equations, such as the Lindblad equation, and introduces concepts of Markovianity. Finally, it delves into the basics of quantum thermodynamics, including quantum heat engines. Students will gain a robust understanding of noisy quantum systems and insights into current research directions, preparing them for advanced studies and research in quantum information science and related fields.
Detailed Syllabus: 1. Review on basic linear algebra; Metric space, Dual space, Hilbert space and bra-ket algebra.
2. Review on unitary quantum mechanics; Unitary evolution, state vectors, uncertainty principle, Schroedinger equation etc.
3. Pure and mixed states, basics on measurement theory, projective measurements, positive operator valued measures etc.
4. non-unitary evolution, tensor product space, bi-paretite quantum systems, global evolutions, non-unitary dynamics, completely positive trace preserving maps, operator-sum representation.
5. Monotones under completely positive operations, basics of distance measures and entropic measures.
6. Selected topics on complete positivity, positivity, Choi-Jamiolkowski isomorphism, Stinspring dilation, entanglement detection.
7. General quantum dynamical equations, master equation, Lindblad equation and its derivation from a few different perspectives, properties of Lindblad dynamics.
8. Basic idea on Markovianity and non-Markovianity from quantum mechanical perspectives.
9. Basic ideas on quantum heat engines and a few other selected topics on thermodynamics.

Course Description: This course delves into the foundational principles of operating systems and their intrinsic relationship with network architectures. Students will explore core OS concepts including process and memory virtualization, scheduling, and concurrency mechanisms like threads and locking. The curriculum further examines data persistence through file systems and protection models, alongside an integrated study of networking fundamentals, data transmission technologies, and basic network security. Practical outcomes include the capacity to develop efficient applications utilizing OS and network services, design task-specific OS modules, and architect robust network-based systems by leveraging system calls.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Introduction, Process and Memory Virtualization – Scheduling, Memory addressing and Paging, and Networking Overview
Unit 2: Concurrency – Threads and locking mechanisms, Common concurrency problems, Data transmission and Network Technologies
Unit 3: Persistence – File Systems, Protection, Network File Systems and basics of Network Security

Course Description: This course provides a rigorous exploration of modern cosmology, focusing on the fundamental physical principles governing the universe's evolution from its earliest moments. It begins with observational evidence, including cosmic expansion and the microwave background, then delves into the geometric and dynamic properties of the universe using Friedmann equations to model various cosmic scenarios. Students will examine the thermal history, including recombination, nucleosynthesis, and the role of cold dark matter. A significant portion addresses the concept of cosmic inflation and its solutions to longstanding cosmological puzzles. Upon completion, participants will be able to explain large-scale structures, analyze cosmic dynamics, calculate properties of model universes, and critically engage with contemporary unsolved problems in cosmological research.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit-1: Universe Observed: Expansion. Isotropy and homogeneity. Age. Cosmic microwave background

Unit-2: Geometry and Dynamics: Universe in the eyes of Newton. Geometry. Mass and curvature. Freedman equations. Model universes: empty universe, matter or radiation dominated universe, multi-component universe
Unit-3: Black-body radiation and the early history: Observation of CMB. Recombination and decoupling. Last scattering. Temperature fluctuations
Unit-4: Very early history of the Universe: Thermal history. Nucleosynthesis. Cold dark matter
Unit-5: Inflation: Flatness, horizon, and monopole problem. Physics of inflation

Course Description: This course systematically explores the fundamental principles governing programming language design, semantics, and implementation. It delves into core paradigms, including functional programming, and foundational concepts like operational semantics, scope, state, control flow abstractions (such as continuations), and type systems. Through formal methods, students analyze how various language constructs are specified and implemented. This understanding enables them to analyze and critique diverse language designs, create domain-specific and object-oriented languages, and specify robust application interfaces.
Detailed Syllabus: Functional Programming: Abstract vs. Concrete Syntax. Racket syntax, Functions, recursion, syntactic extensions, higher-order functions, map, reduce and other combinators.
Operational Semantics: Abstract Reduction Systems, Transition Systems, Reduction, Simplification and Evaluation relations. Judgements and Rules. Rule Induction.
Scope: Identifiers, Scope and extent, Lexical scope, Environments, Dynamic scope and parameters. Closures

State: Stores and imperative constructs, explicit and implicit store references, objects, invariants and safety, interfaces and constructors, inheritance, Parameter passing. Call-by-value, call-by-name and lazy evaluation.
Control: Tail calls, Contexts, continuations, continuation passing style, exceptions, threads.
Types: Types syntax, type safety theorems. Type inference
Special Topics (if time permits): Monads, Concurrency.

Course Description: This course explores the fundamental principles governing semiconductor devices. It begins with the quantum mechanical basis of semiconductor properties and energy band theory, detailing carrier behavior in equilibrium and transport phenomena. Subsequently, the course delves into the physics and operation of key semiconductor structures, including PN junctions, Metal-Oxide-Semiconductor (MOS) devices, MOSFETs, and Bipolar Junction Transistors (BJTs). Students will develop the ability to calculate device parameters, solve related design problems, and design basic semiconductor circuits.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Semiconductor Properties
Unit 2: Quantum Mechanics and Energy Band Theory
Unit 3: Carriers in equilibrium, G-R processes
Unit 4: Carrier Transport
Unit 5: PN Junction physics
Unit 6: MOS & MOSFET
Unit 7: BJT

Course Description: This course delves into the fundamental principles of probability theory and random processes. Students will establish a robust understanding of probability spaces, conditional probability, and various discrete and continuous random variables, including their distributions, expectations, and variances. The curriculum further explores joint and conditional distributions, functions of random variables, and crucial limit theorems like the Law of Large Numbers and Central Limit Theorem. Finally, it introduces the core concepts of random processes, including stationarity and power spectral density. Upon completion, students will be equipped to analyze and apply probabilistic models to real-world scenarios.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1 : Sets and set operations, Probability space, Conditional probability and Bayes theorem.

Unit 2: Discrete random variables, probability mass function, probability distribution function, example random variables and distributions, Continuous random variables, probability density function, probability distribution function, example distributions.

Unit 3: Joint distributions, functions of one and two random variables, expectation and variance, Conditional distribution, densities, conditional expectation, moment generating functions, characteristic functions.
Unit 4: Markov, Chebyshev and Chernoff bounds. Random sequences and modes of convergence, Strong and weak laws of large numbers, central limit theorem.
Unit 5: Random processes, Mean and covariance functions, Stationary processes and wide-sense stationary processes, power spectral density, linear filtering of random processes.

Course Description: This course provides a rigorous foundation in probability theory and statistical inference. It commences with discrete and continuous random variables, exploring their distributions, key properties, and moment generating functions. The curriculum progresses to multivariate distributions, covering marginals, conditionals, independence, and the Central Limit Theorem. The course then integrates statistical inference methods (estimation, hypothesis testing, Bayesian approaches) and introduces fundamental random processes. Students will develop the analytical skills to model and interpret probabilistic phenomena, apply statistical inference techniques, and logically derive theoretical results.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Discrete Random Variables: Probability mass function, expectation and variance. Bernoulli distribution, Geometric distribution, Binomial distribution. Derivation of mean and variance. Sampling with and without replacement. Hypergeometric distribution and Poisson distribution. Derivation of the Poisson distribution as limiting form of Binomial. Derivation of mean and variance. Bounding probabilities, tail sum formula, Markov’s inequality and Chebyshev’s inequality. Probability generating functions and moment generating functions.

Unit 2: Continuous Random Variable: Probability density function, cumulative distribution function, expectation, mean and variance. Moment generating functions and uniqueness theorem. Chebyshev’s inequality. The uniform distribution on (a, b), the normal distribution. Mean and variance of the normal distribution. The Cauchy distribution. The exponential distribution, moments, memoryless property, hazard function. Gamma distribution, moments, Chi-square distribution.

Unit 3: Multivariate Distributions: Cumulative distribution function method for finding the distribution of a function of random variable. The transformation rules. Discrete bivariate distributions, marginal and conditional distributions, the trinomial distribution and multinomial distribution. Continuous bivariate distributions, marginal and conditional distributions, independence of random variables. Covariance and correlation. Mean and variance of linear combination of two random variables. The joint Moment generating function (MGF) and MGF of the sum. The bivariate normal distribution, marginal and conditional distributions, conditional expectation and variance, joint MGF and marginal MGF. Linear combinations of independent random variables. Means and variances. Sequences of independent random variables and the weak law of large numbers. The central limit theorem, normal approximation to the binomial distribution.

Unit 4: Statistical Inference and Random Processes: Point Estimation, Interval Estimation, Hypothesis Testing, Linear Regression, Bayesian Inference. Point Processes, Poisson Process, Discrete Time Markov Chains.

Course Description: This course introduces the foundational principles and practices of modern product management, emphasizing the strategic role in developing technical products for the digital world. It progresses from understanding market needs and crafting robust product strategies to ideation, feasibility assessment, and cultivating an innovative product mindset. Participants will learn to develop comprehensive product roadmaps and release plans, applying agile and lean methodologies for efficient execution. The curriculum equips learners with essential skills to successfully ideate, strategize, and oversee the development and market launch of innovative digital solutions that address complex market problems.
Detailed Syllabus: Module 1: Introduction to Product Management – the Art & Science of Product Management: What is product management; Types of Product Management; Product life cycle
Module 2: Product Strategy: Market Research; Product Value Proposition; Product Strategy (Market Needs, Key Differentiators, Business Goals)
Module 3: Product Ideation & Market fit: Product Ideation; Product Feasibility; Product market Fit; User Journeys
Module 4: Adopting a Product Mindset: Prioritization; People; Process; Progress
Module 5: Product Roadmap: Top-Down Product Strategy; Featureless Roadmaps to feature roadmaps; Roadmaps to Release plans
Module 6: Product release execution: Product Prototyping & Market Validation; Product Development Process (Agile development process, Lean product development); Product release to market

Course Description: This course delves into Product Marketing, emphasizing its strategic integration with product management to build and launch successful products. It systematically covers essential marketing frameworks like the 4Ps and 4Cs, guiding students through developing robust value propositions, including segmentation, pricing, and positioning. Key topics extend to crafting compelling marketing narratives, fostering customer engagement, and constructing actionable sales playbooks. Learners will gain proficiency in applying methods and tools to define, execute, and evaluate comprehensive go-to-market strategies, designing products effectively from inception.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1 – Product Marketing and Product Management: Recap of 1) how marketing is an integral part of Product Management, 2) Product Management fundamentals, 3) Product Market Fit – problem and solution validation
Unit 2 – Marketing Mix: 1) Value Model (4Cs), 2) Marketing Mix (4Ps) and how to use them in tandem to strategize product launch
Unit 3 – Value Proposition and Promotion: 1) Segmentation and User Personas, 2) Customer Journey Mapping, 3) Pricing Mix, 4) Positioning, and 5) Product Branding
Unit 4 – Customer Engagement: 1) Introduction to Marketing Communication, 2) Building a comprehensive narrative for marketing, and 3) Customer Engagement at all stages of acquisition
Unit 5 – Sales Playbooks: 1) What are playbooks? and 2) how to develop an actionable playbook for sales
Unit 6 – Go-to-Market Strategizing: 1) Customer Acquisition Strategies, 2) Defining the GTM Strategy, and 3) Executing the GTM Strategy successfully

Course Description: This course provides a rigorous introduction to Quantum Information Theory, exploring its fundamental principles and applications for information processing. It covers the mathematical postulates of quantum theory, detailing quantum states, channels, and measurements for both closed and open systems. Students will examine various quantum correlations, including entanglement and non-locality, alongside essential mathematical tools such as trace-distance and quantum entropies. The curriculum culminates in an analysis of quantum communication protocols. Upon completion, students will be equipped to analyze information-theoretic aspects of quantum systems and apply these concepts to advanced information processing tasks.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Overview of why the need of quantum information theory: In this part, we will overview the need for quantum information theory. Outline briefly what Shannon information theory means and why and how can we study information theoretical aspects of physical systems obeying quantum theory.

Unit 2: Mathematical formulations of the postulates of the quantum theory: In this part, we will study the postulates of quantum theory pertaining to quantum information theory. We will mainly describe postulates in the form of mathematical statements and rules. We will deal with both closed (unitary evolution) and open (noisy evolution) quantum systems. We will discuss standard theorem statements (e.g., Choi-Jamiołkowski isomorphism) after introducing quantum states, quantum channels, and quantum measurements.

Unit 3: Quantum correlations: In this part, we will discuss different kinds of quantum correlations. We will mainly focus on quantum correlations like entanglement and nonlocal quantum correlations. We will discuss measures and tests to quantify or test these correlations. We may touch upon local hidden variable theories to derive Bell tests for nonlocal quantum correlations.

Unit 4: Tools in quantum information theory: In this part, we will introduce and discuss some of the important tools that are employed widely in the domain of quantum information theory. Some of these tools are trace-distance, relative entropy, fidelity, etc. We will discuss formula and bounds for quantum entropy, quantum conditional entropy, quantum mutual information, quantum conditional mutual information. We will discuss quantum data-processing inequality, strong subadditivity, and other entropic measures and inequalities.

Unit 5: Quantum communication protocol: In this part, we will discuss quantum typicality, packing lemma, covering lemma, and some examples of quantum communication protocols. We may touch upon quantum resource theories and their frameworks if time permits.

Course Description: This course delves into Quantum Mechanics, exploring the probabilistic nature of the quantum world that fundamentally differs from classical theories. Students will master the essential mathematical formalism, including linear algebra and complex analysis, necessary for solving quantum problems. The curriculum covers foundational concepts like the Schrödinger equation and uncertainty principle, progressing through solutions for one-dimensional systems such as the infinite square well and harmonic oscillator. Advanced topics include three-dimensional systems like the Hydrogen atom, angular momentum, perturbation theory, and conceptual challenges like Bell's theorem. This prepares students to analyze complex quantum systems and understand the profound implications of quantum phenomena.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Introduction: The Schrödinger equation and the uncertainty principle
Unit 2: Mathematical Formalism: Review of linear algebra, complex functions, Fourier transformation etc. and the generalized statistical interpretation, Heisenberg picture
Unit 3: Time independent Schrödinger equation: Infinite square well, harmonic oscillator, free particle, delta function potential, finite square well
Unit 4: 3D Problems: Spherical coordinates - Hydrogen atom, angular momentum, spin, two-particle systems, atoms
Unit 5: Advanced topics: Time independent perturbation theory, the variational principle, Bell's theorem

Course Description: This course provides an immersive exploration of Hindi literature, focusing on its historical trajectory and contemporary expressions. Students will engage with seminal works of fiction, poetry, and drama by influential authors like Nirmal Varma, Bhishm Sahani, Ajnyeya, Muktibodh, and Mohan Rakesh. The curriculum also delves into non-fiction and critical theory, examining concepts such as aesthetics versus committed literature and the sociology of literature. Through these readings, students will develop a profound appreciation for literary arts, gain a comparative understanding of diverse literary traditions, and acquire elementary skills in literary criticism, encouraging future creative engagement.
Detailed Syllabus: I. History of Hindi literature
2. Fiction: Nirmal Varma, Bhishm Sahani, Manto, Gyanranjan, Kamaleshwar, Uday Prakash, Ismat Chugtai, etc.

3. Poetry: Ajnyeya, Muktibodh, Nagarjun, Shamsher Bahadur Singh, Raghuveer Sahay, Faiz Ahmed Faiz, Nand Kishore Acharya, Sarveshwar Dayal Saksena, Manglesh Dabral, Vinod Kr Shukla, Kumar Vikal, Gagan Gill, Katyayani, Anamika, etc.
4. Play: Mohan Rakesh (Aadhe-adhoore)
5. Non-fiction and criticism: (i) Pleasure readings; (ii) aesthetics versus committed literature; (iii) Sociology of literature

Course Description: This course establishes a rigorous foundation in mathematical analysis, starting with the fundamental properties of real numbers, sequences, and series, including convergence. It then advances to core principles of differentiation and integration, covering mean value theorems, Taylor series, and multiple integrals. The curriculum further extends to vector calculus, ordinary and partial differential equations, and a comprehensive introduction to complex analysis, encompassing analytic functions, Cauchy's theorems, and residue calculus. Students will cultivate skills in constructing rigorous mathematical arguments, communicating complex ideas, and applying advanced analytical methods to solve diverse problems.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Sequence of real No, Bounded and Unbounded Sets, Supremum, Infimum, Limit points of a set, Closed Set, Countable and uncountable sets. Sequences, Limit points of a Sequence. Limits Inferior and Superior, Convergent sequence, Non convergent sequence, Cauchy General Principle of Convergence, bounded and monotone sequence, Infinite Series, Positive Term Series, Convergence of series of real numbers, Necessary condition, Absolute convergence and power series, Convergence tests for series.

Unit 2: Mean value theorems (Rolle’s Theorem, Cauchy Mean Value Theorem, Lagrange’s Mean Value Theorem), Indeterminate forms, Taylors Series, Partial derivatives. Integration as a limit of a sum, some integrable functions, Fundamental theorem of Calculus, Mean Value Theorems of Integral calculus, Integration by parts, Change of variable in an integral, Second Mean value theorem, Multiple integrals,

Unit 3: Vector, Vector operations, Products, Areas and Determinants in 2D, Gradients, Curl and Divergence, Volumes and Determinants in space. Differential equations of first order and first degree. Linear ordinary differential equations of higher order with constant coefficients. Elements of Partial Differential Equation (PDE).
Unit 4: Analytic function of complex variable, CR Equation, harmonic functions, Laplace equation, applications

Unit 5: Integration of a function of a complex variable, M-L inequalities. Cauchy’s Integral Theorem. Cauchy’s Integral formula. Taylor’s and Laurent Expansion, Poles and Essential Singularities, Residues, Cauchy’s residue theorem, Simple contour integrals.

Course Description: This course delves into Real-Time Embedded Systems, emphasizing the design and analysis of time-critical applications. It covers essential concepts from system modeling to diverse scheduling paradigms, including clock-driven, priority-driven, and multiprocessor algorithms. Students will rigorously analyze schedulability under various conditions, manage aperiodic and sporadic tasks, and address resource access control issues within uniprocessor and multiprocessor environments. Practical outcomes include the ability to critically assess system performance, analyze complex timing constraints, and develop effective scheduling solutions for real-world real-time systems using simulators.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Real-Time Systems – Introduction and Concepts, Modeling Real-Time Systems

Unit 2: Commonly used approaches to Real-Time Scheduling – Clock Driven approach, Weighted Round Robin approach, Priority Driven Approach, Dynamic vs Static Systems, Offline vs Online Scheduling, Preemptive vs non-preemptive
Unit 3: Clock Driven Scheduling – Scheduling Aperiodic and Sporadic Jobs, Schedulability test
Unit 4: Priority Driven Scheduling – Static Priority: Rate Monotonic and Deadline Monotonic Algorithms, Dynamic Priority: EDF Algorithm, Schedulability tests
Unit 5: Scheduling Aperiodic and Sporadic jobs in Priority Driven Systems – Deferrable Server, Sporadic Server, Constant Utilization Server, Total Bandwidth Server and Weighted Fair Queuing Server
Unit 6: Multiprocessor Scheduling
Unit 7: Resources and Resource Access Control

Course Description: This course delves into advanced research topics within information security, exploring foundational cryptographic principles like Elliptic-Curve Cryptography, key management, and access control. It examines security challenges across diverse modern computing paradigms, including vehicular networks, smart grids, IoT, and Cloud/Fog environments. The curriculum further investigates intrusion detection and prevention strategies, alongside the security and privacy implications of blockchain technology and its convergence with AI/ML. Students will cultivate critical thinking, problem-solving, and formal verification skills, enabling them to analyze existing protocols and design, analyze, and implement novel security solutions for emerging threats.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Elliptic-Curve Cryptography (ECC), Key management in hierarchical access control, Key management, user authentication and access control, Proxy signature
Unit 2: Security in vehicular adhoc networks/Internet of Vehicles (IoV), Security in smart grid/smart home, Security in Cloud/Fog computing
Unit 3: Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) and Internet of Things (IoT)security
Unit 4: Intrusion detection and prevention
Unit 5: Blockchain and its security and privacy issues, Blockchain-based AI/ML security

Course Description: This course provides a comprehensive understanding of structural retrofit for existing infrastructure. It delves into the theory and concepts of damage mechanisms in masonry and RC buildings, detailing assessment methodologies, including computational stress analysis. Key retrofit techniques such as RC jacketing, shotcrete, and the addition of shear walls and bracing are explored, alongside their numerical modeling. Students will develop skills to quantify damage, propose appropriate retrofit solutions, apply structural analysis principles, and computationally evaluate the seismic performance of retrofitted structures in accordance with codal provisions.
Detailed Syllabus: Module 1: Basic Concepts Introduction; Retrofit and its concept; Advantages and challenges; Retrofit materials; Difference between repair, retrofit, strengthening and rehabilitation; Codal provisions, Different techniques of retrofit, Mesh techniques: poly-propylene band, industrial geo-grid, chicken mesh, welded wire mesh; Section enlargement techniques: RC jacketing, shotcrete; Addition of structural components: shear walls, frames and bracing; Retrofit of foundation system: micro-piles.

Module 2: Damage Assessment of Existing Buildings Causes of structural damage; Purpose of assessment; Detailed vulnerability assessment; Rapid visual survey; Non-destructive and semi-destructive testing; Numerical assessment of structurally deficient building; Computational stress analysis of structurally deficient building.

Module 3: Numerical Modelling of Retrofit Techniques for Existing Buildings Local and global methods of retrofit; Modelling of various retrofit techniques in software - RC jacketing, shotcrete, shear walls, frames and bracing.

Module 4: Re-evaluation of Retrofitted Building Numerical assessment of retrofitted building; Comparison between structurally deficient and retrofitted building; Check for capacity/drift and strength parameters; Codal provisions and acceptance criterion.

Course Description: This course offers a rigorous foundation in robotic manipulator dynamics and control. It covers rigid body motion, spatial transformations, and mathematical modeling of robot links and joints. The curriculum progresses through manipulator kinematics—forward/inverse, velocity, singularity analysis—and delves into Euler-Lagrangian dynamics. Students will master trajectory planning and explore joint space and operational space control strategies. The course prepares learners to model, analyze, and implement effective control solutions for complex robotic systems.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Introduction to robotics and rigid body motion – robot structure and workspace, transformation matrices, mathematical representation of joints and links, mobility analysis and constraints
Unit 2: Manipulator forward and inverse kinematics – position analysis and velocity analysis, singularities
Unit 3: Robot Dynamics – Euler-Lagrangian formulation and simulation of equations of motion
Unit 4: Trajectory planning and generation
Unit 5: Robot control – joint space control and operation space control

Course Description: This foundational course, "Science I," explores fundamental principles across physics and chemistry, emphasizing both theoretical understanding and methodological approaches. It commences with mathematical modeling and natural scales, progressing to Special Relativity, classical mechanics via Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formulations, and the principles of Quantum Mechanics with applications to molecular structure. The course integrates Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics to explain macroscopic phenomena and material properties. Students will develop robust analytical and problem-solving skills, enabling them to evaluate scientific methodologies, analyze complex systems, and prepare for advanced research.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Mathematical modeling in sciences, (i) geometry and linear algebra, (ii) change and calculus and (iii) chance and probability. Simple models can have complicated behavior: logistic map demonstrates deterministic chaos
Unit-2: Forms in nature. Scales of length, time and energy in nature.

Unit 2: Special theory of relativity: postulates, Lorentz Transformation, Length Contraction, Time dilation, Doppler effect, relative velocity determination, twin paradox, relativistic momentum and energy. Space time graphs, and relativity of simultaneity.
Unit 3: Review of Newtonian Mechanics and its difficulties / failures. Introduction to Lagranian and Hamiltonian formulations, and application to mechanical problems.

Unit 5: Need for Quantum Mechanics. Schrodinger equation for time-dependent and time independent scenarios. Application to atoms and molecules; provide qualitative picture of orbital hybridization to explain the molecular structures
Unit 6: Review of Thermodynamics and introduction Statistical Mechanics and applications to problems of relevance. Lasers. Fermi statistics, bandgap in semiconductors.

Course Description: This course, Science Lab - I, offers a foundational introduction to hands-on experimental techniques across fundamental scientific disciplines. Students will engage in diverse experiments spanning optics, including measurements of optical rotation, wavelength, and diffraction phenomena. Chemical investigations focus on potentiometric and pH-metric titrations, kinetic studies, and concentration determinations via Beer-Lambert's Law. Additionally, physical measurements involve determining material properties like Young’s Modulus and investigating Earth's magnetic field. This comprehensive lab experience equips students with practical proficiency in experimental design, data acquisition, analysis, and interpretation, fostering essential laboratory skills for scientific inquiry.
Detailed Syllabus: 1. Unit-1: Determination of the Specific Rotation of Sucrose and Composition of Sucrose Solution by a Polarimeter
2. Unit-2: Potentiometric Titration of a Mohr Salt Solution with Standard K2Cr2O7
3. Unit-3: Kinetic Study of the Decomposition of H2O2 in the Presence of FeCl3 Solution and the Effect of the Catalyst on the Rate Constant
4. Unit-4: Verification of the Beer-Lambert’s Law with a given solution and the determination of the concentration of a solution
5. Unit-5: Determination of pKa of a Weak Acid by pH-Metric Titration Method
6. Unit-6: Newtons Ring Method to measure Radius of Curvature of Plano-Convex Lens
7. Unit-7: Determination of Young’s Modulus of Material of a Beam by Method of Flexure
8. Unit-8: To determine the number of rulings per unit length of a diffraction grating
9. Unit-9: Stewart and Gee’s Method for Determining the Magnetic Field of the Earth
10. Unit-10: To Measure Slit-Width and the Separation between two Slits of Double Slit, by Observing Diffraction and Interference Fringes and to Compare them by Microscopic Measurement

Course Description: This course explores the foundational principles and advanced methodologies of signal detection and estimation theory. It rigorously covers optimal estimation techniques, including Minimum Variance Unbiased (MVU) estimation, Cramer-Rao bound, and practical estimators like Maximum Likelihood (MLE), Least Squares (LSE), and Bayesian approaches. Concurrently, it investigates hypothesis testing, Neyman-Pearson criterion, and likelihood ratio tests for optimal signal detection under diverse conditions, ranging from deterministic to random signals with known or unknown parameters. Students will develop analytical and design skills to implement optimal detectors and estimators, applying these robust techniques to complex problems across engineering disciplines.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Estimation Theory - Minimum Variance Unbiased (MVU) Estimation, Cramer Rao lower bound, Fisher Information, Neyman-Fisher factorization, Sufficient and complete test statistics, Rao Blackwell-Lehmann-Scheffe theorem.

Unit 2: Estimation methods - Best linear unbiased estimation (BLUE), Least square estimation (LSE), Maximum likelihood estimation (MLE), Bayesian Approach, Numerical methods - Newton Raphson and Expectation maximization (EM) methods.

Unit 3: Detection Theory - Hypothesis testing, Neyman-Pearson (NP) theorem, Likelihood ratio test (LRT), Receiver operating characteristic (ROC), Minimum probability of error, Bayes Risk, Minimum Bayes risk detector, MAP detector.

Unit 4: Detection methods–Detection of deterministic signals - Matched filter for WGN and non WGN, Binary and M-array signal detection using matched filter. Detection of random signals - Estimator-correlator and linear model; Detection of deterministic signal with unknown parameters - Composite hypothesis testing, Generalized LRT (GLRT), Bayesian approach, Rao test, Wald test.

Course Description: This course explores the fundamental principles of signal processing, starting with continuous-time signal analysis using Fourier Transforms for LTI systems. It then covers sampling, reconstruction, and analog-to-digital conversion, addressing issues like aliasing. The curriculum progresses to discrete-time signals and systems, utilizing DTFT, Z-Transform, and efficient DFT implementations (FFT). A significant focus is on designing FIR and IIR digital filters. Students will develop practical skills in analyzing complex signals and systems, applying various transforms, and designing effective digital filters, preparing them to tackle real-world problems through simulation and research-based analysis.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Fourier transform (FT) of continuous-time signals, analysis of linear and time invariant (LTI) systems using Fourier transform
Unit 2: Sampling and reconstruction of bandlimited signals, analog-to-digital conversion, aliasing, quantization
Unit 3: Analysis of discrete-time signals and systems using Fourier transform (DTFT) and Z- Transform
Unit 4: Discrete Fourier transform (DFT) for finite length sequences, efficient implementation of DFT using radix-2 fast Fourier transform (FFT) algorithms
Unit 5: Digital filter design, techniques for FIR and IIR filter design

Course Description: This course provides a comprehensive exploration of Software Quality Engineering, focusing on the principles and practices essential for designing and analyzing high-quality software systems. It covers fundamental concepts of process and product quality, measurement techniques, and quality tactics within the software development lifecycle, including formal methods and V&V perspectives. Specialized topics include usability, accessibility, secure software engineering, and quality considerations for intelligent systems. By engaging with current research and applying well-established principles, students will develop the ability to critique existing work, identify open problems, and synthesize novel solutions for complex quality challenges.
Detailed Syllabus: The course will cover the following topics: - Process and Product Quality - Measurement Fundamentals – Why, What and How? - Qualities and Tactics - Software Development Life Cycle – V & V perspective - Formal Methods and Quality - Usability and Accessibility - Qualities in intelligent Systems – Model, Data and System - Secure Software Engineering - Other research topics

Course Description: This course introduces foundational principles and practical methodologies for software systems development. It systematically covers essential Unix-like environments and shell scripting for automation. Students will delve into web programming fundamentals, including client-side technologies (HTML, CSS, JavaScript) and server-side scripting with Python. The curriculum further encompasses basic database programming, software development lifecycle (SDLC) concepts, and an overview of networking and security principles crucial for modern applications. Upon completion, students will be proficient in evaluating application ideas, developing diverse scripts and small-to-medium scale applications, and extending existing software solutions.
Detailed Syllabus: Linux and Shell Scripting, HTML, CSS, JavaScript and related libraries, Python, Basics of SDLC, Simple Queries, Networking and Security concepts.
1. Shell Programming - Linux basic commands, script writing, Swiss-army- knife tools (vi, grep, awk, sed ..)
2. Web Programming - Intro to basic concepts of the World Wide Web (WWW) and tools used to develop web apps. -Client-side & server-side scripting (HTML, XHTML, CSS, Java script, Python,)
3. Database Programming, Networking and Security

Course Description: This course introduces Spatial Informatics, focusing on the principles and applications of Geospatial Information Systems (GIS). It delves into fundamental concepts of space and digital representation of geospatial data, covering techniques for data collection, management, and advanced analysis, including spatial queries and network analysis. The curriculum also explores data compatibility, web-GIS, and 3D GIS. Students will learn to prepare and analyze spatial and temporal data, interpret complex outcomes, and design research projects to address real-world challenges in various domain areas, uncovering critical patterns.
Detailed Syllabus: Course Structure (each of approximately 1–2-week duration):
1. What is Geographical Information Systems (GIS)?
2. Fundamental concepts of Space
3. Geospatial data and its Digital representation – Vectors and Raster
4. GIS Data collection, Editing and Data formats
5. Data structures for Spatial data and Spatial data management (Geospatial database)
6. Spatial Data Query and Analysis – Spatial Analysis, Network Analysis
7. Data compatibility - Projections and Georeferencing
8. Spatial reasoning and uncertainty
9. Web-GIS, GML and Map services
10. Geospatial applications in few areas like in Hydrology (Water flows and floods); Ecology and Environment; Land use and Land cover; Urban planning and Transportation; etc.
11. Topics in Spatial Informatics 1. 3DGIS 2. Open-Source Initiatives inGIS/RS

Course Description: This course explores the foundational principles and practical applications of spatial thinking and spatio-temporal analysis. It covers essential methodologies for spatial data acquisition and processing, including traditional surveying techniques, modern Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSS), and advanced digital photogrammetry. Students will delve into fundamental concepts of geodesy, earth's gravity field, and error management in geospatial data. The curriculum integrates the conceptualization, representation, and computation of spatial information, equipping learners to implement diverse measurement techniques and critically evaluate their relevance within various geospatial contexts.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit-1: Concept of Space and Time: Geographical entities and Phenomena, Properties of Space, Size and Scale, comprehend spatial and temporal data throughout the processes of conceptualization, representation, computation, and visualization.

Unit-2: Surveying: Principles of Surveying, Measuring equipment, Techniques, Levelling, Triangulation and Trilateration, Plane Table Surveys, Modern surveying equipment- Total Station, The mathematical model and errors, Random and systematic errors, adjustments techniques.

Unit-3: GNSS: Intro to GNSS; GNSS survey, Keplerian laws, inertial coordinate systems etc., Overview of GNSS: GLONASS, GALILEO, BIDOU, IRNSS satellite systems etc., Differential GPS: GNSS Basic Observables: GNSS Surveying Techniques. Planning and field observations: Networking, data post processing. GNSS applications to Global, Regional and Local issues

Unit-4: Digital Photogrammetry: Fundamental principles and techniques of Photogrammetry surveying, camera calibration, image orientation, stereoscopic viewing, and digital image processing, photogrammetric methods for terrain modeling, Digital elevation model (DEM) generation Integration with other geospatial technologies (LiDAR, UAVs).

Unit-5: Geodesy: Introduction to geodesy & its development; Earth and its gravity field. Earth and its atmosphere – physical properties, Introduction to GPS- its components, Instruments & processing software, GPS signals. GPS data collection, Data Handling-, GPS data processing, Errors in GPS data – Satellite Geometry, Multipath errors & corrections; Accuracy of GPS data. Datum transformation. Geoid modelling.

Course Description: This course explores the fundamental principles governing the interaction of matter with electromagnetic radiation across various energy regimes. It systematically covers atomic and molecular spectra, applying both classical and quantum mechanical models to explain electronic, vibrational, and rotational transitions. Detailed discussions include Raman, Infrared, Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR), and Electron Spin Resonance (ESR) spectroscopies. Students will develop the analytical skills to interpret complex spectra, apply theoretical models to spectroscopic phenomena, and calculate molecular properties derived from experimental data.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Introduction: Classical mechanical description of spectroscopy, quantum mechanics and energy quantization, energy-level diagram, energy spectrum: electronic states, vibrational states, rotational states, excitation and relaxation, absorption and emission of electromagnetic waves by materials
Unit 2: Atomic Spectra: Spectral series of hydrogen and alkali atoms, selection rules, L-S coupling, many-electron atoms, isotope shift, hyperfine splitting of spectral lines

Unit 3: Molecular Spectra: Electronic spectra of diatomic and polyatomic molecules, Born- Oppenheimer approximation, Franck-Condon principle, absorption and emission spectra, fluorescence and phosphorescence, Jablonsky diagram, effect of solvation of electronic spectra, rotational spectrum of a diatomic molecule using a rigid rotator model, energy levels and spectrum of a non-rigid diatomic molecule, effect of isotopic substitution on rotational spectra, vibrational spectrum of a diatomic molecule using the harmonic and anharmonic oscillator models. vibrational- rotational coupling in a diatomic molecule, molecular spectra of chain molecules

Unit 4: Raman and Infrared Spectroscopy: Classical and quantum theory of Raman effect, normal vibrations of CO2 and H2O molecules, vibrational and rotational Raman spectra, basic concept of infrared spectroscopy, interpretation of Raman and IR spectra, identification of Raman-active and/or IR-active modes based on symmetry arguments
Unit 5: Introduction to Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR), and Electron Spin Resonance (ESR) spectroscopy

Course Description: This course offers a comprehensive exploration of speech analysis and computational linguistics, examining the fundamental linguistic units from phonemes to sentences and their acoustic manifestations. It systematically covers core methodologies for phonemic, prosodic, and text analysis, including advanced topics like visual phonetics, intonation modelling, and neural language models. Students will learn to apply computational linguistics foundations to analyze state-of-the-art speech applications such as ASR and TTS. The curriculum develops practical skills in modeling pronunciation, intonation, and text features, enabling the design of effective algorithms for robust speech processing systems.
Detailed Syllabus: (Please list the order in which they will be covered, and preferably arrange these as five to six modules.)
Unit-1: Speech and linguistic basics -- Description of frames, phonemes, syllables, words, phrases, sentences and its use in speech-based feature computation.
Unit-2: Linguistics in speech analysis -- Overview of speech applications (such as ASR, TTS, Speech pathology etc..), use of phonemes, graphemes, prosody and text.

Unit-3: Phonemic analysis -- Phonemes and its accents, visual phonetics (Spectrogram, articulatory videos), pronunciation variations and modelling, grapheme to phoneme conversion, phoneme accent variations and identification.

Unit-4: Prosodic analysis -- Prosodic structure, word and syllable prominence, prominence detection and its applications, Intonation and its modelling (such as ToBI etc..), pitch and prominence variations, intonation identification, pauses, disfluencies and its detection, speech rhythm and speaking rate.
Unit-5: Text analysis -- language modelling, neural language models, metrics, text normalization, character-based speech analysis.

Course Description: This course provides a comprehensive foundation in speech signal processing, focusing on the intricate mechanisms of human speech. It delves into the fundamental principles of speech production and perception, progressing to detailed analysis techniques. Topics include LTI speech modeling, extraction of key speech events like pitch and formants, and advanced analytical methods such as STFT, linear prediction, and cepstral analysis. The course also examines prosody and excitation source characteristics. Ultimately, students will be equipped to understand and design algorithms for various speech processing applications, including recognition, synthesis, and speaker identification.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Overview of signal processing, speech production, speech perception, typesof speech, and LTI model of speech production.
Unit 2: Pitch, formants, epochs and vowel region extraction.
Unit 3: Speech analysis: STFT analysis, Linear prediction analysis and cepstralanalysis.
Unit 4: Prosody analysis and excitation source analysis of speech.
Unit-5: Applications of speech processing such as speech recognition, speakerrecognition and speech synthesis.
